'Eye of the Temple' is a highly entertaining adventures puzzle game for VR with a large expansive open world.
You will have to explore this world and reach further locations by figuring out and solving puzzles.
These puzzles are related to the environments you are in and so it is very important to remember where you have found potentially unsolved puzzle elements that you will have to revisit later.

Early Access Gameplay:
Vidéo YouTube™: It's Indiana VR Jones!! (Eye Of The Temple - Early Access Gameplay) 
Vues : 137
'Eye of the Temple' is a highly entertaining puzzle game for VR with a large expansive open world. You will have to explore this world and reach further locations by figuring out and solving puzzles.


In terms of movement, Eye of the temple has a unique offer that I have only experienced in a few VR games and that is a complete roomscale based controls,
you will have to take certain short routes in the game by stepping into your play area with your legs.
There are no controls to move in the game, make sure your playing space meets the 2m x 2m minimum playspace requirement.

In the game you will need to use a 'whip' which was useful to indiana jones just like this one and his adventures will have the same use in Eye of the temple,
you'll need to use these to reach certain levers or objects that you can't reach by hand and aren't super far away either,
also this whip will be useful for fighting the enemy creatures you will encounter.
After defeating these creatures or destroying vases or other objects, you will be able to collect rubies that you can trade for another type of crystal later in the game to enter the temple.

Eye of the temple is also a good VR example game that you can show to VR virgins because through the way of moving the motion sickness gets rid of the first experiences.
Also, the puzzles are not too challenging and the environments in the world are very varied with heights and depths, caves and zones with lava and lots of traps.

Évaluation publiée le 1 décembre 2021
Eye of the Temple von Rune Skovbob Johansen, einer Einmannschmiede, ist ein ebenso wunderbares wie fast einzigartiges VR-Abenteuer. Das an Indiana Jones angelehnte Spiel wird nämlich komplett in Roomscale gespielt.

Es gibt bisher leider nicht viele Spiel am Markt, die sich in dieser nur in VR möglichen Bewegungsart präsentieren. Von ein paar kleinen Techdemos abgesehen gab es wirklich nicht viele Programme in den letzten Jahren, die sich die immersive Bewegungsart des Roomscale zu Nutze gemacht haben. Eye of the Temple ist im Prinzip das einzige komplette Spiel und zudem noch ein tolles Indiana Jones-mäßiges Abenteuer.

Wir sind also sozusagen Indiana Jones und müssen uns durch eine riesige antike Tempelanlage bewegen. Als Archäologe untersuchen wir dabei die mit Fallen gespickte Ruine, um die Geheimnissen einer untergegangenen Zivilisation zu lüften.
Eine schöne Aussicht kann man auch genießen, hat man keine Höhenangst. 
Une capture d'écran de Eye of the Temple
Par : Moriar

Dafür bewegen wir uns aber nicht wie in den meisten Spielen per Stick oder gar Teleportation, sondern mit unseren eigenen Beinen. Wir laufen buchstäblich selbst durch die große Anlage. Wir treten auf schwebende Plattformen und vor allem auf rotierende Steine oder auch in die ein oder andere Lore. Diese Roomscaletechnik gaukelt uns perfekt die Illusion vor, dass wir lange Wege in der Ruine zurücklegen, aber in Wirklichkeit bewegen wir uns nur auf mindestens zwei mal zwei Metern.
Wie ein echter Archäologe sind wir mit Fackel und Peitsche ausgerüstet. Die Peitsche hat eine sehr gute Physik und fühlt sich richtig kernig an, wenn wir mit ihrer Hilfe Hebel bewegen oder gar Feinde erledigen...
Je tiefer wir in die alte Anlage eindringen, desto schwieriger wird das Überwinden der Hindernisse. Auf den rotierenden Steinen müssen wir rückwärts laufen, um nicht herunter zu fallen, hier und da müssen wir uns ducken und laufen gleichzeitig, damit die Decke, die sich unaufhörlich auf uns herab senkt nicht zerquetscht. Sehr anstrengend, kann ich sagen und ein tolles Indianafeeling.
Rotierende Steine und bewegliche Plattformen 
Une capture d'écran de Eye of the Temple
Par : Moriar

Die Rätsel sind einfach bis herausfordernd genug, dass ich im Laufe des Spiels schon stecken geblieben bin. Vor allem in den Abschnitten, in denen man seine Bewegungen genau mit der Umgebung abstimmen muss. Sehr anstrengend.

Ist unser Spielbereich frei von echten Gegenständen wie Möbeln oder gar Haustieren und wirklich auch 2 x 2 Meter groß, laufen wir eigentlich keine Gefahr mit ihnen zusammenzustoßen. Eye of the Temple nutzt die oben beschriebenen Elemente so gut aus, das wir förmlich vergessen im Kreis zu laufen. Perfekter kann Immersion in VR kaum sein.

Allerdings gibt es auch ein zwei Wermutstropfen, da Eye of the Temple nur von einer Person geschrieben wurde, ist die Abwechslung nicht wirklich hoch. Wir benutzen meist immer die gleichen Elemente und müssen oft das selbe erledigen. Feuer machen und Knöpfe bzw. Hebel aktivieren.
Plattformaufzüge an der Wand 
Une capture d'écran de Eye of the Temple
Par : Moriar

Auch grafisch ist Eye of the Temple kein Überkracher, evtl. hat Rune Skovbo Johansens schon eine Questportierung im Hinterkopf gehabt, als er das Spiel für den PC entwickelte. Aber für ein Einmannprojekt ist es sicherlich auch schwer, denn irgendwann soll das Produkt ja auch auf den Markt kommen. Dafür ist das Design aber stimmig und nicht zu comiclastig.

Auch die Länge von ca. 7h ist gut gewählt, denn Eye of the Temple ist schon ein schweißtreibendes Abenteuer, und ich glaube dass man es nicht in einer Sitzung durchspielen kann.

Eye of the Temple ist ein wunderbares Experiment, die Möglichkeit, den eigenen Spielraum zu nutzen, um sich kilometerweit zu bewegen, ist einfach toll und macht das Spiel einzigartig. Eye of the Tempel darf in KEINER VR-Bibiliothek fehlen. Es ist ein Pflichtkauf.

English:
------------------------------>
Eye of the Temple by Rune Skovbob Johansen, a one-man forge, is a VR adventure that is as wonderful as it is almost unique. The game, which is based on Indiana Jones, is played entirely in roomscale.

Unfortunately, there are not many games on the market so far that present themselves in this type of movement, which is only possible in VR. Apart from a few small tech demos, there really haven't been many programs in recent years that have made use of the immersive movement type of Roomscale. Eye of the Temple is basically the only complete game, and it's also a great Indiana Jones-like adventure.

We are Indiana Jones, so to speak, and have to move through a huge ancient temple complex. As an archaeologist, we investigate the ruins, which are full of traps, in order to uncover the secrets of a lost civilization.

To do this, we don't use a stick or even teleportation as in most games, but rather our own legs. We literally walk through the facility ourselves. We step on floating platforms and especially on rotating stones or even the one or other lore. This roomscale technology perfectly gives us the illusion that we are traveling long distances in the ruins, but in reality we are only moving on at least two by two meters.
Like a real archaeologist, we are equipped with a torch and a whip. The whip has very good physics and feels really pithy when we move levers or even finish off enemies with its help....
The deeper we go into the ancient facility, the more difficult it becomes to overcome the obstacles. On the rotating stones we have to run backwards in order not to fall down, here and there we have to duck and run at the same time so that the ceiling, which is constantly descending on us, doesn't crush us. Very exhausting, I can say, and a great Indianafeeling.

The puzzles are easy to challenging enough that I've gotten stuck throughout the game. Especially in the sections where you have to match your movements exactly with the environment. Very exhausting.

If our play area is free of real objects like furniture or even pets, and is really even 2 x 2 meters, we don't actually run any risk of colliding with them. Eye of the Temple uses the above elements so well that we literally forget to walk in circles. Immersion in VR can hardly be more perfect.

However, there are also two downsides: since Eye of the Temple was only written by one person, the variety is not really high. We mostly use the same elements and often have to do the same things. Make fire and activate buttons or levers.

Also graphically Eye of the Temple is not an overachiever, maybe Rune Skovbo Johansens already had a quest port in mind when he developed the game for the PC. But for a one-man-project it is certainly difficult, because the product should be released someday. But the design is coherent and not too comic-heavy.

The length of about 7 hours is also well chosen, because Eye of the Temple is a sweaty adventure, and I don't think you can play through it in one sitting.

Eye of the Temple is a wonderful experiment, the possibility to use your own game space to move for miles is just great and makes the game unique. Eye of the Temple should not be missing from ANY VR library. It is a must buy.

Évaluation publiée le 21 juillet 2022
The absolute best use of roomscale I've ever seen in a VR game. How the developer designed the whole game so that you're only moving around 2x2m square and yet feeling like your're exploring a huge open space is insanely clever and well done. Every aspect of this game is expertly designed.

Everything you do in Eye of the Temple is dictated by your physical movement, there are no button/joystick controls here and nor should there be. The game starts a little on the easy/slow side (I assume to get you used to moving around), but the puzzles ramp up at a good pace to a good level of difficulty where I had to stop and take in my surroundings to think for a bit, but never felt stuck. I enjoyed having to intensify my movement for certain areas, with the final boss fight in particular being a very memorable example that really got the adrenaline pumping. One very minor gripe is that the whip felt a bit finicky to begin with, and I felt I had to aim a lot lower than felt normal, but I quickly got used to this and had no trouble through the rest of the game.

This is one game that is going to stick with me for a long time as truly utilising VR to it's full potential, and for that reason I'm sure it will remain one of my favourite VR game for a long time. If you have VR and the required space, you have to play this game.

Évaluation publiée le 14 octobre 2021
Summary:
Great game with clever design, guiding you through a huge temple and its outside area, very immersive, unique and fun!
You really need those required 2x2m playspace.
There are a few accessibility options.
Might not be the best choice if you're afraid of heights.
I started playing with Index, but later switched to Quest + Airlink, worked fine for me.

Initial review:
I'm not through yet, but I can already say, this game is very immersive, unique and fun! The atmosphere created by the music and sound effects is great.

Amazing how well thought through everything is! Not only the great level design which works without any artificial locomotion (be sure you have the required 2x2m playspace, you'll need it!), but also everything about lighting.
I love the light & shadows in the outside areas and the torch light inside. Even if you happen to stand in the dark at some point (the torch burns down) you are not lost, you can still see the stones and rollers at least, because they have an illuminated sign on them.

There are also some accessibility options, like setting the crouch height or switching torch and whip.

Update:
After about 1.5 hours of gameplay, I switched from playing on Index to Quest (1) via Airlink, because I figured going wireless would be worth the (for me) worse comfort of wearing the Quest. The game works fine on Quest and it was totally worth it for me. Wireless it's even more amazing! If you have that option, I'd totally recommend trying it.

I noticed that if you die in the same spot a few times in a row, you get a puzzle specific, but not detailed piece of advice :D I got 2 or 3 of those and they usually helped me. Not by giving a solution, but making me stop and think again. Is there anything the developer didn't think about?

The temple is huge! Every time I thought that's gotta be it, I found yet another new area.

The whole game is awesome, I enjoyed it a lot, but my favourite part was the way to the last room. That felt amazing! (sorry, no spoilers here)

If you are afraid of heights, this might not be a game for you. Or good practice to get over it.

Évaluation publiée le 17 octobre 2021
Disclaimer: I did early testing for this game so got it for free, but also gifted two copies so I count that as having paid for it.

To me, this is a VR game not to miss. Why?
  1. It is a room-scale game, that means you move around physically, this is rare nowadays while being the most immersive type of VR game for me.
  2. The movement mechanic is a wholly novel solution, I believe unique to this game at the time of writing, and it's so clever it hurts my brain! You step between blocks in physical space, and then the blocks can move around so you always return to the center of your space. It is a meticulously designed world that enables this. 😌
  3. You also get to interact with a torch and whip, and again the game is so well crafted that you only use the whip in the room center, where it's safe to swing your arms around. And this whip feels so natural it's almost worth playing the game just to experience it! 🤣
  4. There are no mid-game loading zones, the whole world is there for you to explore, with no pause screens.
  5. And while it's one big world, there are varying environments, outdoor and indoor areas, different lighting and materials.I won't spoil what you get to see, bit it's more than
  6. The game ramps up and down in difficulty in a well paced manner, I never felt totally overwhelmed and had time to pause in between challenges.
  7. The game does have some artificial locomotion as well, but there also exists comfort options to try and mitigate any negative effects, so try out which works for you if you need them.
  8. There are almost no buttons to learn, the whole game relies on your feet and moving your hands to perform all actions. The only button use I found was to open the in-game menu, and even then that can be opened on the desktop mirror by pressing escape, so someone else can manage that, allowing for an entirely button-less VR experience.
  9. The sense of adventure is great, the world is filled with puzzles, both safe and slow ones and ones that put pressure on you to both survive and figure things out at the same time! It is very satisfying to figure things out and clear an area.
  10. You will probably die plenty of times, but the automatic reset is super quick, and you get very frequent check-points, which it auto saves so you can quit at any point and return whenever you please. Very convenient.
  11. All in all it took me 5½ hours to clear the game the first time, this is with me knowing the main mechanics beforehand from my testing, so you might get even more time out of it. It is a physical game though, as you move around, so to me it feels like more! The game is to me cheap for what you get, and to get this much time and enjoyment out of a game which needs such exact level design is just insane.
  12. There are also achievements and a speedrun mode, both which are things I will look into next, but at the time of writing I have only cleared the main campaign without focusing on anything else.
And, if you are a content creator...
  1. It has a context aware camera for LIV if you use a virtual avatar, it's glorious!
  2. It has support for the latest LIV plugin in general, with fake lighting it looks great.
  3. People won't believe you are actually moving for real, it's so rare nowadays.

Conclusion
It's just a great game, and one of a kind, don't miss out if you have VR and the space for it!

Ah ah! How funny! I was skeptic about the apparently nth Quest game with poor graphics. Well, this time I was wrong! Remember: exception proves the rule! :) EOTT has not the best VR graphics for sure, but it comes with very smart design. It's a pure 100% VR game. Only VR can give you the feeling of losing balance and falling despite the fact that in reality you can plant your feet firmly on the floor of your room! Oh man! What a weird sensation! Your brain is tricked despite the limited graphics! No way you try to convince yourself it's just a 3D display in front of your eyes and nothing you see is true! Ah ah! I'm still laughing for the weird sensation! I was just taking some steps in my 3 m x 3 m play space! But in VR I was a sort of Indiana Jones jumping from stone to stone inside a huge ancient temple littered with traps and mysterious gears! Oh my! I cannot believe how easily EOTT fooled my mind! Everytime I had to take a step or a little jump to land on the moving stones and not fall down, I really felt like I had to coordinate my body parts in order to not lose my balance! And when sometimes I was not good enough, I remained with one foot on the stone and the other foot raised in an attempt to regain balance! As if I really couldn't place my foot in the void, even though in reality I was on the floor! Oh my! Delicious! This is VR magic! Room scale experiences are the best!
I'm so lucky to experience the today frontier of VR gaming after 43 years of traditional flat gaming! It's so refreshing, so different, so cool! I cannot understand people skeptic about VR, who do not want to wear the headset and explore this new frontier despite having the possibility. I know, it's an immature tech yet. But so were the old consoles at the turn of the '70s and' 80s, I remember them well! And I'm sorry for people suffering from motion or cyber sickness or for people who cannot afford VR rig. It's so funny to explore and discover this new frontier of gaming. Happy VR to everyone! :)

WE DESPERATELY NEED MORE GAMES LIKE THIS IN VR!!!

(spoiler-free review)

This game features some of the most creative VR gameplay of any VR game that exists today. I would even go so far as to say that there are some aspects of this game that are better than anything you would find in Half-Life: Alyx. For example, the very clever use of physical space, the way that the player is moved around in reality by the obstacles in the game (but never forced into a wall!), the ways that you are seemingly always returned to the center of your playspace after a complex traversal of obstacles, and the steady pace at which more and more complex VR mechanics are introduced. Every single block and obstacle in this game is placed with very very careful consideration. While playing this game, I got so immersed that I accidentally disconnected my Valve Index headset cable by pulling on it too hard while moving (a wireless or overhead cable management system is highly recommended). I have never done that before! Despite playing with a tethered headset, rarely did I feel like it was preventing me from enjoying the game. For all of these reasons, I have to highly recommend this game to any VR enthusiast.

In addition, I have to say that the final few levels of the game are SO SO GOOD. Just wait and see :D :D :D

Uczucie jest niesamowite, to już nie to samo, co stanie w miejscu i machanie rękami.

Gra, jest ładna i przyjemna, to taki Indiana Jones VR. Można ją wypróbować, korzystając z wersji demo, ale pełna gra oferuje dużo ciekawsze zagadki i pułapki. Potrzebne miejsce to kwadrat o boku 220x220cm (200 i margines), a w trybie speed run 300x300 cm.

Jestem bardzo zadowolony z zakupu, to dobry stosunek jakości do ceny.

Évaluation publiée le 15 mai 2022
I had more fun with this game than with any other VR title in a long time. I consider myself a seasoned VR gamer.... I've had four different VR headsets since 2016 and played countless games. I never get motion sickness, and never do any of the ridiculous things some inexperienced people do that we've all seen on YouTube - such as falling over or crashing into things while playing VR games. At the beginning of this game, there are warnings telling you things like "don't lean on the walls you see in the game", etc. I read these warnings, rolled my eyes and thought, "of course not, who would be dumb enough to do THAT!" Well, apparently I am!

This game is INCREDIBLY immersive. A think a big part of it is that you are actually using your feet to do all the walking in the game. For me this (and the beautiful graphics) made me forget I was in VR and there were even a couple of instances where I actually DID try to reach out and brace myself against a virtual wall, only to stumble and nearly fall over. Once I even pulled a muscle, so beware! Also a few times I nearly fell over because I felt like I was losing my balance - my brain really believed I was stepping on and off moving platforms next to a deep chasm. But these things are what make the game awesome!! Isn't that what we are working towards with VR anyway? Ultimately someday we want our VR experiences to be so real and immersive that we can barely differentiate between VR and reality. Well, this game is a step in the right direction!

This game is very well made, of high-quality, and polished - clearly a lot of work went into its development. The draw distance is far and flawless - even when there are a lot of moving parts in the distance. I only encountered one bug (I got stuck and couldn't progress), but this bug is apparently an extremely rare occurrence because everybody else seems to play through and never encounter it. I posted about the bug in the discussions forum, and the developer replied VERY quickly offering to repair my savegame file, and had me back playing in no time.

This game also has some amazing level design. It must have been quite a challenge to create such a large virtual environment within which you can navigate using your actual feet, but yet you are kept from ever actually moving outside your 2m by 2m play area. HOWEVER, if you are like me, try to have a little extra space for "stumbling" room! I'm sure this was overkill but I actually removed both cars from the garage and that gave me a huge play space so I never had to worry about hitting anything. I do this when I play games such as Superhot also. I played Eye of the Temple using the Oculus Quest 2, connected to my PC wirelessly via Remote Desktop (fortunately the wi-fi signal in the garage is strong).

The puzzles in this game were not the most challenging I've seen, but they were good enough to provide an amazing "Indiana Jones" type VR experience that I will never forget. I have high hopes that a sequel will be made someday!

Évaluation publiée le 19 octobre 2021
This is truly one of those rare mind-blowing VR experiences. No matter how many 2D trailers and screenshots you look at, you have no idea what it really feels like putting on the hmd to enter the magic portal and be present in the world of Eye of the Temple. Is it a game? - I more consider it an Indiana Jones simulator :-) In this ... sim ... you'll feel like having been walking many steps in different directions, while you in the physical world never really leave the center of your play space. Feels like some sort of magic ;-)

The game requires a large play area of 2 x 2 meter - or 6 feet x 6 feet, and that must be floor space with no objects blocking. My play space (floor space) is 1.5 x 3.5 meters - and I decided to give the game a try. The game does not support re-centering or thumbstick turning (neither snap nor smooth), but to my amazement the dev has now added the possibility to turn the world left or right (=same as 90 degrees snap turning. This needs to be done inside a menu). This means I can now play the game with no problems! (Well, at least for now, I have not finished the game)

The game is totally awesome - really messes with your mind due to the real walking. Be careful not twisting the hmd cable too much though! The game is one of the most convincing VR experiences I've had. Graphics are simple and get the job done, but still look nice/great. Performance is awesome too - I got solid 90 fps using Index res 500% (yes, five-hundred), you basically just need a GTX 970.

This game really feels like being Indy - or playing some real-life Montezuma's Revenge, lol. Highly recommended.

Évaluation publiée le 22 juillet 2022
There are several moments in this game that would be worth the price of admission by themselves. More than once I said aloud, "Oh, now that's cool."
Its clever use of locomotion in room-scale VR allows for a pretty special experience exploring its abandoned yet magically-possessed jungle temple.
Be aware that it needs a full 6'x6' clear playspace. Anything less than that and you risk rendering certain parts of the game impossible. Additionally, I played on an Oculus Rift CV1 and had a great time, but this is ideally suited for a cordless headset, or one with some method to ensure your cord isn't getting wrapped around or trapped under your feet. This is especially true for the very hectic speedrun challenges.
It's got a demo which gives you a pretty good idea of gameplay, but almost all of the really cool moments are in the full version.

Indiana Jones estaría satisfecho
Sorprendido ♥♥♥ el titánico tamaño del mapa. No hay niveles como se podría imaginar, es todo un enorme y único "level". Esto le da una continuidad y visión al mundo muy inmersiva.

Un látigo y una antorcha, eso es lo único que llevamos y necesitaremos. Nuestro movimiento y desplazamiento realizados en nuestro sitio de juego "real" es lo que exige este juego: es SÍ o SÍ "Room Scale". Y es esto, que quizá no el 100% de los jugadores disponga, el único handicap para no aceptar el reto del juego. Si disponemos del espacio requerido utiliza un inteligente sistema de desplazamiento que consigue no romper la ilusión de recorrer largas distancias sin realmente hacerlo.

Son unas 4/5 horas de aventura resolviendo sencillos puzles y sorteando trampas.

A nivel técnico simplemente cumple: los gráficos son sencillos pero muy efectistas.
Destacar una excelente física del látigo además de un muy buen efecto de iluminación de la antorcha. Quizá el audio sea la parte más justita en cuanto variedad y calidad del sampling; creo que una mayor "fidelidad" de los efectos sonoros le sentaría fenomenal (soy exigente ♥♥♥ este tema, sí).

Conclusión
Recomendado. Jugabilidad sencilla, exigente ♥♥♥ la capacidad espacial del jugador y revolucionario en su concepto de locomoción.

Seguro que lo re-visito de nuevo en un futuro.

Mi nota: **** (4/5)

정확하게 VR 게임이 지향하는 방향을 이해하고 있다.

몸을 직접 사용하여, 몰입도가 엄청 뛰어나고 게임 자체는 단순하지만

게임 자체 볼륨도 큰 편이라 가격대비 매우 만족한다.
이 게임은 성장 가능성이 많이 보이며

Évaluation publiée le 23 octobre 2021
This is an excellent example of what VR can be. This game got me feeling like I was a part of this world like no other vr game has in recent memory.

It's sadly very short, with the story mode only taking 4 hours for me, but it was an excellent use of those four hours!

It's a fairly slow-paced game, with only brief moments of anything intense.

The physical locomotion of this game is very satisfying. As long as you have a 6'x6' play space, you never have to touch your control stick at all, and just physically walk everywhere.

If you're afraid of heights, like my wife is, you might have trouble, as a lot of the areas in this game are quite high up. I love it, but she did not lol


It should also be noted that I played it entirely via proton on Linux, with zero issues.

Évaluation publiée le 11 décembre 2022
I own 44 VR titles right now, and this game is my SECOND FAVORITE. EofT is SPECIFICALLY MADE for ROOM-SCALE VR. There is no other way to play it, and for good reason. The movement mechanics are unique and they have figured out a way to let you get around the entire game without leaving the 2 x 2 grid that is your real world space. You WILL look very silly to anyone who is watching you play as you walk backwards while crouching, or squat down to avoid overhead flames WHILE still trying to use your whip to kill flying beetles! I really enjoyed the torch/whip mechanics, and the added ability that the whip gains later in-game. Sometimes you have to figure out how to deal with the torch going out... Also, it is fun to ride around the mine cart once you gain that ability. NOT a game for people who are afraid of heights or are claustrophobic! To win you are going to have to: walk across skinny, wooden planks over a chasm as well as stand completely still while a huge slab of rock moves past your body right in front of your face... among many other puzzles/challenges. Great stuff!

Évaluation publiée le 16 aout 2023
This game is simply amazing. If you have never played a room scale VR game before, then you are missing out. This is probably the most immersive VR game I have ever played (to the point where I actually reached out to steady my self on a wall that wasn't there - epic fail).

You do need a space of about 2m x 2m (although I would recommend 2.5x2.5 with nothing expensive near by), as the game has you moving on a 3x3 grid. The mechanics of this game though are amazing, and the more you thing about what this developer has achieved, the more you want to tell others to buy it.

The 3x3 grid sounds lame, but the way that you navigate the game, you soon forget the fact that you are moving around in such a confined space. With turns, moving bricks and rolling stones, you lose total track of where you are. What really twists your melon though, is that you have a whip in the game, that is used to whip items, but the only time you ever use it, is when you are on the centre square of your play space! Crazy.

If you have the ability to play this wireless, then I would recommend it. If you are wired, then I would recommend running a steam overlay like TurnSignal so that you can keep track of cable tangle.

Everyone I have recommended this to, that have purchased it, has agreed how amazing it is, and when we start talking about the navigation mechanics, they are blown away with how clever it is.

3.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 octobre 2021
When I first started this game, I thought the no-locomotion, purely room-scale design was neat, but feared using only moving platforms to get around would get stale, or boring, repetitive or tedious.

I clearly underestimated the creativity of this developer. Throughout my ~3.5 hours of gameplay I was continually introduced to new creative mechanics, made incredibly intuitive and natural to learn in the way only VR games can achieve. Transportation is kept entertaining by keeping you on the lookout for pots, gems, and the layout of the level you're in so you can figure out where to go next and how to solve puzzles. You may spend half the game waiting for floating platforms to arrive, but it'll never feel like a huge chore.

The puzzles, traps and enemies pose a good challenge, and you're constantly solving new problems. The non-linear design of the dungeon gives players an excellent feeling of exploration and the fast-travel mechanic through the minecart rides helps break monotony even further without feeling like cheating (like most teleportation-based fast travel systems).

None of the mechanics overstay their welcome and the sheer creativity of everything this game has to offer makes it well worth its full price. I can't think of a game that's designed itself around such a unique and immersive locomotion mechanic, not to mention executing it this well.


My only complaints are honestly really minor. It would be nice to have physical collision on the torch and whip so they don't phase through objects, and maybe have a full body view so you can more easily see what block you're standing on (and while obviously quite overkill and niche, full body/feet tracking support would be nice for better platform recognition and even more immersion). Immersion is this game's best selling point, and a little extra could go a long way.

Regarding bugs: I encountered some soft-locks with regards to the gem conversion and tower activation (if you use both too fast the gem converting one gets kinda stuck), easily fixed by intentionally dying and respawning, and there were one or two times I felt I fell off a platform when I shouldn't have... But that's about it. Nothing massively game-breaking.

Lastly, I played through this whole game with my chaperone completely disabled, and only had two light incidents with the real world. The level design is excellent and ensures you are effectively never tempted to move any part of you outside the chaperone bounds (provided your playspace is big enough of course), while still giving you a surprising amount of freedom of movement when necessary.


Final verdict: Surprisingly one of my favorite VR experiences of this year. Very glad I came across this game and tried it. If you have even the slightest interest in what a game with purely high-immersion, roomscale locomotion would feel like, this is a must play.

乗り物が止まったガックンって感覚がダメな人は酔い止め飲んどいたほうがいいだろうけど、基本はなくて大丈夫そう。
トロッコで酔わないのはすげぇぞ。回転オフにしたら流石に酔うので、背景と移動の時差があまりないのかな。設定に強めのトンネルエフェクトがあるので配慮はだいぶされてる。

自分のキャリブレーションがブレてるってのもあるだろうが、2.5m×2m程度でも壁にぶつかったので安全を確保するなら3m×3m欲しい。物は絶対にどけろ。

Évaluation publiée le 20 octobre 2021
This is the most immersive game I've played this year. The use of room scale with the unique locomotion makes it feel unlike any other game. There is no locomotion like a traditional FPS game, you ride on floating cubes and walk on rollers. The game always keeps you within your chaperone boundary though.
I'm also really impressed with the level design. They all work really well and are fun to play. You need to plan and watch the maze to figure out how to get through.
It's also a huge, beautiful environment, but with simple textures that are frame-rate friendly.
Comfort: the game often puts me slightly off balance when I try to quickly navigate through the maze, but I find this is part of the charm and makes it feel feel like I'm actually there. The first time riding a roller feels very strange, but I quickly got used to it.
♥♥♥♥: because you need to walk around within your room scale bounds (and are often taking steps backwards) I would step on the headset cable a lot. It is more enjoyable to play it wireless or use an overhead pulley system if you can.

Évaluation publiée le 20 octobre 2021
Multiple VERY GOOD THINGS all together in one game. Rare. Each by themselves would be great: Clever locomotion with your own body (without running out of space), vast and beautiful scenery (at heights that give the tummy butterflies), great whip action, gentle and not-intrusive (but not absent!) guidance (in the form of where the gems are gone you know you've been AND a bird to follow AND clues on walls AND messages from the bird you unlock), clever puzzles in a friendly order (harder ones after you have had fun, and want more!), and even a roller-coaster type movement which you direct yourself -- but you have to earn it! And the roller-coaster isn't just some passive easter egg at the end ... it is useful/necessary to get to all the territory you've uncovered without "crawling along," and to get to new territory not otherwise accessible. Seriously, if Steven Spielberg or George Lucas made VR games instead of movies ... this is the VR game they would come up with. It works at so many levels. Great atmosphere music as well.

I love this subtle touch: Kids and/or thrill-seekers can smash the pottery and get gems ... but folks who don't like the feeling of "busting up the place" (esp. a Temple that could be a museum) can "nudge" the pottery without breaking it, and still get the gems, and are able to know when there are no more gems in the pot. There is a freedom of movement here, and almost built in necessity to go back to collect what you missed the first time ... which just makes hanging out in this game all the more fun.

Those that want a "rush" can see how fast they can propel themselves.
Those that want a "tour" can take things (especially the transitions between creepstones) one step at a time ... except where there are time challenges, which are few, and for me welcome.

I would easily pay $60 for this game, having played it (and ... still not done after 4+ hours). I would gladly pay 3X what I did pay, and more. Clearly the work has been put into it. It is carefully and masterfully and playfully crafted.

Évaluation publiée le 1 novembre 2021
As far as VR games go, this one is a gem. While there have been experimental games with nothing but real-world locomotion (for lack of a better term), this is the first full game utilising the concept and it does so masterfully.

In case you haven't heard and are reading this because you are on the fence about the game: There is no artificial movement in this game at all. No stick movement, no teleport, nothing. The whole world is completely navigated by physically moving around in your playspace. The way the game uses that small space to traverse a huge gaming world is nothing short of genius. And most of all, it's really fun.

Thankfully the game doesn't rely on that novel concept alone, but is actually throwing diverse challenges at you along the way. From dodging obstacles while on a moving platform to fighting some creatures now and then (not very often, thankfully, it's definitely a puzzle game, not a fighting game!) to figuring out how to traverse certain rooms, it never gets boring.

There are also 4 secret idols hidden throughout the game and I have to say, finding those was one of the highlights of my gaming "career". They are hidden very well, but not frustratingly hard to find. Just perfect. Plus, once you find the respective entrances you have a whole new area with new challenges to overcome until you can call one of the elusive idols your own. Finding all the secret rooms and getting the 4 idols has easily doubled the playtime I got out of the game.

On top of all that, there is a speedrunning mode being unlocked upon finishing the game. With the latest update, that lets you speedrun the full game but also smaller challenges comprising of the individual sections of the game, ranging from 2-8 minutes in length each. Compare your times on the global leaderboards!

This is a truly fantastic game with a very interesting concept. If you ever wanted to feel like Lara Croft or Indiana Jones, this is the game for you. And even if you haven't.

Just get it already, you won't regret it!

Évaluation publiée le 17 octobre 2021
Eye of the Temple is a very smart game, and a game done with a lot of craft and love for the medium. It captures perfectly the whole Indiana Jones vibe, with the exploration of exotic ruins and avoiding traps and uncovering treasures and relics.

The main system is tied to the requirement to have a 2x2m playing area. The space, which you can see in the welcome screen, is divided into a grid of tiles, which is what you'll be walking from and carefully balancing on. But the levels are designed in such way that you'll advance ona bigger map just by stepping in the right moving platform, or walking backwards a few steps while on the rolling cylinders. So without knowing you'll be physically relocating back and you'll never run out of space even when you're walking normally.

The whip and torch are really fun to use and as the other visual elements in the game they're very well done. The environments are colorful and pleasant, it's a fun place to begin with.

I recommend this game both to newcomers to VR and to longtime fans because this is a pretty unique experience to play.

There's also a nice community and the dev is always eager to inform the userbase of new developments, which is something we should appreciate.

Last but not least, the dev was so awesome to make this game support LIV for mixed reality recording, and it makes sense because it's a match made in heaven, it's the perfect way to show this very physical game which is great to look at from the outside. The unique gameplay really shines.

So I'd say, in 2021 whatever headset you have, this is a must play. Put your furniture against the walls to make place, center properly the play space, and onward to adventure!

"Eye of the Temple" is so incredibly good, I'm thoroughly impressed!
You definitely need the 2m*2m space, but it's absolutely worth moving furniture for it.
It took me just under 5 hours to finish the main game, and another 3 hours to find the hidden locations, which were at least as much fun as the main game.
And I will play it at least one more time, as it is incredibly fun and I don't know of anything comparable at the moment!
Everyone who can free the needed space should at least check out the free demo "Eye of the Temple: First Steps" and then decide for themselves. The demo shows the starting area, the main game then gradually introduces more areas, ideas and challenges, so I never got bored at any point. Just great!

Évaluation publiée le 3 janvier
Eye of the temple es un juego vr en escala de habitación, lo cual quiere decir que te moverás tu en la realidad para avanzar en el juego (es recomendable tener almenos un espacio de 2 metros x 2 metros). Nos pondremos en la piel de un explorador tipo Indiana Jones que se adentra en un templo antiguo y nos moveremos subiendo a diversos mecanismos móviles (y a una montaña rusa jeje) que nos irán llevando por diversas zonas mientras completamos diversos puzzles, matando escarabajos voladores asesinos a latigazos y esquivamos diversas trampas de fuego o pinchos por el camino.

VIsualmente es bonito sin ser un portento gráfico y la ambientación está muy bien conseguida.

La mayor pega del juego es que quizá al principio es muy sorprendente y te parece realmente ingenioso (que lo es, y mucho), pero puede acabar haciéndose un poco repetitivo al final pese a no ser muy largo. Igualmente lo recomiendo mucho,

Évaluation publiée le 14 octobre 2023
확실히 기존 타 VR게임 대비 새로운 시도인 건 확실해 보입니다.
저 또한 여럿 플랫폼을 통해 VR 게임을 보유, 플레이 해봤음에도 불구하고 초반엔 적응기가 필요했고,
체험시켜 줬을 때, VR 입문자가 아님에도 멀미를 느끼는 사례도 직접 목도했습니다.
인지해야 하는 대표적인 특징들은 이 정도로 압축할 수 있을 것 같습니다.

1. 2m x 2m 정도의 공간이 필요합니다.
- 공간 인지를 잘 못하거나, 공간이 딱 저정도로만 나와 난해함을 겪을 경우 해당 사이즈 정도의 저가형 러그나 매트를 구매해 바닥에 깔고 이용하심을 추천드립니다. 피부로 현재 위치를 체감할 수 있게 도움을 줍니다.

2. 초반 튜토리얼처럼 진행되는 구간에서, 반복적으로 굴러보심이 좋습니다.
- 플레이를 하면 결국 왔다갔다 하며, 의도치 않게 그런 진행이 될 것이라 생각은 합니다만,
기존과 느낌이 다르기에 적응기를 가지고 플레이를 시작하는 게 장기적인 측면에서 도움이 될 것으로 보입니다.

3. 결국 모션은 헤드로 감지합니다.
- 우리가 발을 아무리 바삐 움직여도 내 포지션은 헤드에 착용한 하드웨어가 감지합니다.
너무 과한 모션과 움직임으로 보다 더 어지러운 플레이 혹은 오프라인에서 상해가 없도록 주의하시는 게 좋겠습니다.

그 외엔 전반적으로 흥미롭고, 인디아나 존스를 떠오르게 하는 플레이에 가깝습니다.
확실히 킬링타임 그 이상으로 즐겨볼만한 재미와 가치는 있는 게임이라고 판단합니다.
그런 측면으로 본 게임을 추천드립니다! 멋진 모험 되세요!

Non recommandé
6.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 aout 2023
"Eye of the temple" est un jeu de plate-formes en VR qui prend place dans un temple maya perdu au fin fond de la végétation d'une chaîne montagneuse et qui mélange "Fort Boyard" et les "Indiana Jones" (notre personnage porte un chapeau, manie le fouet et peut se déplacer dans un wagonnet). J'aurais adoré adorer ce jeu tant l'ambiance est sympa, l'endroit sympa, le level design sympa et la progression bien fichue. Malheureusement, il souffre d'un point noir considérable, à savoir le déplacement. Le déplacement est toujours un peu l'éternel problème des jeux VR mais là, les concepteurs de "Eye of the temple" ont poussé le bouchon et le vice très loin puisqu'ils ont décidé d'imposer des déplacements physiques sur l'aire de jeu. Pour rejoindre les différentes plate-formes mouvantes ou progresser sur les blocs roulants que l'on rencontre en permanence et sur lesquels tout le jeu est basé, il est impératif en effet de se mouvoir en vrai régulièrement, sur un mètre ou parfois plus. Vous me direz qu'il n'y a rien d'insurmontable là-dedans et que ce choix renforce l'immersion, sauf que le système est incroyablement raide et dirigiste : si vous ne voulez pas mourir, il faut suivre les plate-formes et les blocs là où ils vous emmènent et à aucun moment il n'est possible de se recentrer au milieu de la zone de jeu si l'on est amené à s'écarter de celui-ci. Aussi, si vous vous retrouvez en train de piétiner les limites de votre zone, que ces limites soient des murs, des meubles, votre belle-mère ou que sais-je encore, vous allez devoir rester dans cette position inconfortable jusqu'à ce que le jeu vous ramène au coeur de votre espace. Pour ceux qui, comme moi, possèdent un casque avec un fil et disposent d'une aire ludique pas fantastique niveau taille, l'expérience peut rapidement virer à l'horreur. Si encore les concepteurs avaient prévu plusieurs options de déplacement dont des mouvements virtuels à la manette, notre déception n'aurait pas lieu d'être mais rien de cela n'a été mis en place, aussi incroyable cela puisse paraître. Quand on aspire au statut de professionnels du divertissement vidéoludique, voilà qui s'appelle une faute grave. Pour conclure, "Eye of the Temple" s'accommode mal avec la superficie domestique et s'avère surtout taillé pour les salles de jeu VR à 30 euros l'heure.

No joke: THIS IS THE GREATEST VR GAME EVER MADE!! SERIOUSLY!! Obviously we all love half life... but THIS game is aaaamazing!! You are literally INSIDE the game... you REALLY think you are WALKING through giant caverns... even the heights freak me out in the game -- I hate heights and this game genuinely scares me at times via the height.

I can think of no better VR game that has better immersion than this. Seriously.

And yes... shooter games are fun... but this game is REAL virtual reality where you REALLY think you are in the game and REALLY walking (in real life) and REALLY feel like you are moving on elevators and various sliding platforms.

GET THIS GAME!! This is my all time favorite and will certainly be the first game to show folks who want to experience VR. This game does require a good amount of space, but that is a GOOD thing... im tired of VR games where I'm literally standing in place and merely moving my controller to move forward (like in half life). That blows!! In this game, if you want to walk forward, you WALK forward.

GET THIS GAME!!!

Évaluation publiée le 9 juillet 2023
VR 게임 중 꽤 드문 편에 속하는, "방을 직접 걸어다니며 플레이하는" 룸스케일 VR 게임이다. 이런 류의 게임이 별로 없어서 그렇기도 하지만, 이 게임은 나름 이런 장르를 대표하는 게임이기도 하다.

이러한 장르의 게임 중에는 TraVRsal 이나 Tea For God 처럼 비현실적인 공간 (겹친 공간)이 나타나는 게임이 있는가 하면, 내가 밟고 있는 플랫폼이 이리저리 움직여서 "현실적인 공간"을 직접 걸어다닐 수 있는 게임이 있는데, 이 게임은 후자에 속하는 게임이다. 내가 밟고 있는 플랫폼이 움직인다는 특성 상 어지럼증과 멀미를 유발할 수 있으므로 상당히 주의해야 한다. 나 또한 VR게임에 입문한지 3년 6개월이 넘게 지났고 이제 어떠한 종류의 멀미도 겪지 않는데도 불구하고, 처음 게임을 할 때 상당한 어지러움을 느꼈다.

맵을 이리저리 돌아다니며 보석을 모으고, 채찍과 횃불을 이용해서 퍼즐을 풀고 적과 싸우고 여러가지 함정을 헤쳐 나가는 게임이다. 함정이나 퍼즐의 종류는 평이한 편인데 사실 퍼즐이라고 할 것도 없이 그냥 맵을 따라서 이동하다 보면 자연스럽게 해결이 되는게 거의 90%이고, 적 또한 (나름의 중간보스와 최종보스만 빼면) 사실상 한 종류의 적만 등장한다. 따라서 이 게임은, 내가 직접 (움직이는 발판과 발판 사이를 밟아서) 맵을 돌아다니며 클리어를 해 나가는 재미를 추구하는, 즉 "내가 직접 움직여서 게임을 깬다" 라는 면에 초점을 맞추고 있는 게임이라고 볼 수 있다.

이러한 게임이 드물기 때문에 개인적으로는 VR을 샀다면 한 번쯤은 (VR 게임에 대한 식견을 넓히기 위해서라도) 꼭 해보는게 좋은 게임이라고 생각한다. 게임 자체도 나름 탐험하는 재미가 쏠쏠하고, 숨겨진 아이템들도 있어서 찾는 재미도 존재한다. 이 게임을 해 보면 알겠지만 플레이어가 실제로 방을 돌아다니면서 벽에 부딪치지 않고 맵을 이동할 수 있게 만들어야 하기 때문에, 대충 만들 수 없고 나름의 공식에 의해 정교하게 만들어진 맵이라는 걸 알 수 있다.

한가지 문제점이라면, 만약 메타(오큘러스) 기기로 이 게임을 플레이할 경우, 플레이공간이 자동으로 동기화가 안 되기 때문에, 보다 정확히 말하자면 "링크/에어링크에는 플레이공간의 중앙을 센터로 고정하는 기능이 없기 때문에" 게임을 할 때마다 일일히 리센터를 해 줘야 한다. 그냥 하면 안 되고 상하좌우 간격과 방향까지 정확히 리센터를 해야 하는데, 이를 게임을 실행할때마다 계속 해 줘야 한다. 현재 이 게임은 퀘스트 버전으로도 출시되었는데, 만약 퀘스트 버전으로 나온 게임에 이러한 문제가 없다면 퀘스트판을 구매하는 걸 권장한다

(참고로 퀘스트판 tea for god이랑 travrsal에는 그러한 문제가 없고, 게임 자체가 알아서 중앙을 잡아 주므로 일일히 리센터를 안 해도 된다.)

遺跡を探索するためには自分が、前へ進む、後ろ歩きする、屈む、腕を振る、などの動作をする必要がある。

4時間30分ほどでクリア。

ルームスケールを活かした独特な移動方式が楽しいゲームでした。

Even if I probably won't continue playing Eye of the Temple, I'm recommending it.

This is because the game is brilliant - I just don't like the slow pace.
While I was playing, I was absolutely amazed by how well the concept works and how much thought (and work) was obviously put into this. Several times I took of my Valve Index to see how badly entangled the cable was (I'm using a pulley cable management system), but it just wasn't!

But as I said, the pace is too slow for me. I like fast movement in VR like running, jumping, flying, etc. But here you're "forced" to take your route step by step, which is too tedious for me personally.
Still I think that this game is a must-try, as it's super unique and very well implemented!

Évaluation publiée le 22 janvier 2023
Cool game!
Get it for the innovative movement mechanics if you have the play space and VR legs for it.
The story is light, puzzle elements are on the easy side and the story takes about 4 hours.

Verdict:
I liked the game.
Would've been nice to have a deeper story and it felt a bit tedious at times, especially when I had to backtrack to fix something I didn't figure out early on how to activate.

I absolutely love innovation and this game has the innovative movement mechanic where you traverse the world only by moving in real life, so there's no stick or teleport movement. Although the concept of moving by stepping from moving platform to moving platform is brilliant, I would've liked it be mixed up with more normal walking in the play space. Maybe explore balancing on beams more over lava or heights while being attacked or dodging swinging obstacles. Would've also been cool to fly over the temple area using something like a zipline or even a hang-glider where you need to steer by shimmying from side to side while hanging on to a horizontal bar. I'm sure ideas like this must have popped up during development but didn't fit the budget.

Really hoping the future brings more games where real world movement is used.
So far I've come across these:
* Eye of the Temple
* Tea for God
* Spellbound Spire
* Sömmad (1 level so it's more like a tech demo)

------------------------------------------------
Story:
The story is quite simple. As you play, you learn the history of what has happened and what your part in the story is and how the story will end. Still you want to experience that ending, explore the world and beat the game, so I guess the story is sufficient to give context to the world you are in and adds a bit to the motivation for progressing.

Puzzles:
The puzzles are rather simple and revolve around which path to take or which levers to pull to be able to get to a certain place. I didn't need a walk-through guide to complete the game.

World:
They managed to make the areas of the temple feel different. Some areas have lava, water, pits, spikes, flame and high drops which makes it feel like you're exploring new areas and progressing.

Game length:
It took me a little over 4 hours to complete. After completion I had 56% of the achievements so the game would be longer if you are an achievement hunter. There's also a speedrun mode where the game keeps speeding up if you're fast at switching platforms. This can be used as a workout session and also has global leaderboards. I think it's pretty neat but I don't think a lot of players have tried it since I reached 20th place on my first try.

As for the story mode I think the length was just right. If it had been longer there would need to be more variety in gameplay or more excitement and depth to the story.

Backtracking annoyance:
I had to backtrack some areas to activate an artifact, which I didn't know how to activate at first. Backtracking is never fun, but they made it a easier to find and get to these artifacts later in the game by using a device that helps you see the missing artifacts through walls and also the mine cart helps you travel quickly around the area. It also helps see that you pick up red gems as you move around so if you don't see a trail of gems, you've taken that path before.

Évaluation publiée le 18 janvier 2023
As a VR veteran from the first month I have seen many good things over the years. This game was a welcome and impressive surprise!
It looks simple but comes with an unique and creative concept (super smart locomotion), wrapped in a nice setting (Tomb Raider/ Indiana Jones etc.) and is unfolded in a good pace (not too hard, always something new till the end). Depending on your puzzle solving skills and urge to explore all corners, the main story is about 4-6 hours but not boring or unnecessary stretched in return. I have not encountered a single bug, so its fleshed out. I can recommend it for the full price because its fun and unique like “A Fisherman’s Tale” or “Moss”.

If you have big issues with heights you will face a big challenge. You need at least 2x2m space, must never jump, and should start slowly to get used to the concept. Best played with a wireless headset. Hence (and because of the simpler graphics) I see it well fitting in the Quest/Vive/Pico-universe. Done by a single developer!? Impressive and respect!

Évaluation publiée le 9 janvier 2023
Very nice and polished VR experience, but not for beginners. I myself nearly fell over a few at the beginning until I got my head around how to deal with the accelleration of the plattforms. My girlfriend involuntarily did the splits and is currently healing her strain - not bad and party her own fault, but it happened despite her VR experience with other titles.
Tip: Start slowly, don't rush and be focussed at start. The game takes up quite a bit of space as you progress on moving platforms, but they are cleverly positioned so you're never far from your starting position. I recommend an area of ​​about 3x3m for safe gameplay. I played the free demo ("first steps") first and unfortunately the savegame is not being transferred to the paid version.

Too bad it's not a very long game, I'm hoping for a sequel. I can fully recommend this game, well done game developer!

一応ゲームをクリアしました。
デモ版をプレイしてプレイスペースが十分に確保できていることを購入前に確認しましょう。
Tomb Raiders好きな自分には楽しかったです。
日本語字幕も出るので安心です。

3.0mx3.0m近いスペースが必要です。
このプレイスペースさえ確保できれば、快適に楽しくプレイできると思います。
ゲーム自体は面白いと思うので、引っ越しするなり部屋の模様替えをするなりしてプレイエリアを是非確保してプレイをお勧めします。

※高所恐怖症には、結構厳しい場面が多いです。

Évaluation publiée le 31 juillet 2022
Unique VR room-scale "platformer" with huge open levels, casual puzzles and extremely satisfying movement and whip usage.

Room-scale locomotion is one of the most immersive things in VR that makes virtual places feel very real. And here it is used with full force, while requiring only 2m x 2m play space. Rolling blocks are great idea that enables player to traverse long distances on foot without any space warping or "changing room around the corner" tricks. Which in turn allows Eye of the Temple to have giant open levels, where other room-scale games have to do with series of small rooms.

Évaluation publiée le 16 mai 2022
Raiding a Tomb in VR.

Graphics/Performance

This game works under Proton/Linux but gets very laggy in some areas. I was still able to complete the game through the lag. Most areas have a decent frame rate. Ran using an RTX 3090.

Gameplay

This game is really well thought out. You play the whole thing without needing any button presses or joystick input from the VR controllers. Just full motion controls and using your body to move around in your playspace. Even minor things like focusing your attention using a ball of light to look or move into a reset position are well thought out. The vibration of the whip and the feedback when your controller hits a wall/obstacle is really immersive.

Sound

Music fits the theme of jungle tomb raiding. Voice actress for the narrator is okay.

Final Thoughts

There's not many well polished VR titles that have a decent playtime and a satisfying ending. The story is vanilla but the puzzles and platforming are what kept me invested. It's a novel use of your playspace and if you have the room, I highly recommend this one.

2 thumb up.

5.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mai 2022
The game is built around the core mechanic of walking backwards in real life to move forward in-game, using a rolling drum. This is a very novel approach and allows for the illusion of infinite space. This mostly works well, but you don't always take the exact same amount of steps, so there is still a little off-center drifting that occurs. My playspace is 3.5x5m and I found myself triggering the boundaries a few times. This is not a big deal, but it does break the immersion.

It feels a little clinical (heavy on math, light on story), but I think it fits the theme. I'd love to see the same mechanics used in a more story-driven game, as a means of locomotion only, rather than the star of the whole show.

Well worth your time and money, but I'd suggest ample playspace and a wireless headset to really get the best experience from it. I played this game all the way through on my Focus 3 and experienced zero bugs or glitches. It's polished and well made.

8,5/10.

Évaluation publiée le 22 février 2022
UPDATE STARTS After playing through a few more levels of this game, I felt the need to update my review.

I'm what you call a mature gamer, with well over 5,000 hours of gaming and I can honestly say that Eye of the Temple is in my Top 5 gaming experiences of all time, maybe even the best gaming experience I have ever enjoyed...


UPDATE ENDS

Played 100's of VR games for many years, and THIS game got me excited about VR again.

The limiting factor of VR is that you are constrained to your physical environment and it doesn't matter how games try get around that, you are pretty much always aware that you are in your room - for the fear of running into or punching a wall - UNTIL NOW.

This game mechanic is next level room scale. It actually means that you can literally feel as if you are traversing huge areas, while in actuality, you are only walking around a 2m play space. It is absolutely genius. A very few number of other games have tried similar things, but not on such a grand scale, or with such amazing effect.

I really hope this game gets the success it deserves and motivates the developer to take this to another level. I'd love to see more of this type of game, perhaps a darker more sinister theme, or a slightly less "floating block" environment that was more believable.

I did not believe a new VR game, in my old Vive Pro headset, in my same 2m play space, would evoke such new wonders at this stage in my VR experience.

Thank you so much to the developer!

It’s been a long time since I’ve played a game or experience in VR which has given me that huge wow factor partly because I’ve been playing VR for such a long time now but my mind was absolutely blown with this one! 🤯

The game revolves around physically moving about your playspace (you’ll need at least 2m by 2m) onto moving platforms around this huge temple where you’re solving various puzzles. You’re armed with a torch to light fire (which aids with the puzzle solving) as well as a whip to wrap around levers. Makes you feel extremely immersed and a bit like Indiana Jones in VR!

This is a great game.
Disclaimer; I did not pay for the game, but keep reading...

Go get it !

Recommandé
7.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 janvier 2022
The roomscale VR is the highlight of this game, (if you have the minimum required space). You walk and turn freely in the world (there is an option for snap turn) by moving onto series of moving platforms, these platforms make it feel like you are traversing really far into the map, but really you're walking in circles in your playspace, while looking like a dork dodging/ducking, rolling (on logs) and cracking your whip.

The addition of a "spectator mode" with various camera controls (3rd person, a few first person options, and different camera behaviors) makes the game fun for more than one person, because if you're taking turns you can watch what the other person is doing, and figure out the puzzles together. There is even a little model of a camera that floats along with you (I think just in 3rd person camera) that reminds you of the presence of what the other person is seeing.

Overall light-puzzles accompanied by movement/timing puzzles, few and light narrative moments, sense of space through roomscale locomotion, and the artstyle make the experience something any VR enthusiast with enough space should try. It's not a crazy wow factor (aside from feeling like friggin Indiana [redacted] tm explorer guy), but it does make you feel that initial charm of trying your first VR headset on again, with the novel roomscale experience. A neat understated gem.

Évaluation publiée le 7 janvier 2022
Wow, GET THIS GAME. Even if not on sale. It is like Tomb Raider in VR, but that doesn't even properly describe it. It is awesome!

I had been holding off on this game for a while as I usually wait until games are a bit older and on sale before getting them. But a lot of VR games don't appear on sale as often or as drastically as non-vr games as -understandably- as it is still a growing field and there are a lot of indie VR developers out there who maybe can't afford to do that with their games. However, I decided to jump in on this one after seeing the critical acclaim and it did NOT disappoint.

It seems this is an indie developer, but the level of polish, thought and creativity involved in this game would make you believe it was one of the big studios.

It is kind of mind boggling how much effort was put into creating such an immersive game that has you moving constantly exploring a huge temple without straying far from your VR space. It works SO well. Love, love, love the idea and wish more games had this sort of movement instead of just relying on the joystick. I also like the use of the whip to attack enemies and do other tasks. Very smart.

I think I'm kind of a VR veteran at this stage, having played the vast majority of the well known games, but this one really surprised me as to how fun it is. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

Évaluation publiée le 7 décembre 2021
I'm new to VR and this game was a great example of what I thought VR should be. It was so immersive I felt myself responding to the environment.. sweating, heart pounding. Using the body is required: ducking, sidestepping, swinging your arm. You definitely need the recommended space and probably a little more since I found myself close to out of bounds from time to time. The movement mechanic is very clever and ties into the story. As for the story, it's fairly generic but works well. At this price point it's well worth your time if you enjoy exploration, temple diving, and solving light puzzles. Many games charge more for price paid per hour gameplay, and this game has secrets to discover as well. I've only played a handful of VR games and this is one of my favorites. I hope to see more like this.
 
isotope

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 novembre 2021
I wrote a review of the demo ages ago - Yes, there is a free demo. Try it. This is an updated version.

Wow. First off, let's say this is a REALLY clever game.

It's the first time I've ever played a VR game that feels like you're actually physically moving in infinite space, where the clever level design means that you're really moving within your confined play area without realising it. You have to try it to truly appreciate it. I'm 6+ months on from having played the demo, and nothing else I've tried feels as real as this.

The demo seemed very polished - there are full games out there with far more sharp edges. The full version is just as nice - just bigger. The graphics are great, and the sound spot on. All together hugely immersive.

One small thing; this is best played with a pulley system (or something keeping the cable out of your way). Otherwise, when you step forwards onto a roller, and then shuffle backwards (you'll see what I mean you when try it), there is every chance you'll end up stepping on your cable. The constant need to monitor where the cable is will hurt the immersion that this game works so hard to build up.

If you have a 2mx2m or larger roomscale playspace, then you owe it to yourself to try this out! If you don't, just burn your furniture until you do!

Évaluation publiée le 30 novembre 2021
Between pcvr(Steam and Oculus)and the Quest 2, I can't even guess how many VR games I've bought since mid 2016, and I'm not even counting the dozens and dozens of titles I had on my PlayStation VR before it broke. All that being said, I very rarely feel the need to review a game, but I'll make an exception for this. I think it was with the release of Saints and Sinners that I first started to see some decent physics in vr games. I know that it's what Boneworks is known for (though I haven't played that one yet)Those physics were the last big gameplay innovation introduced to VR that I know of, until now. There are other roomscale experiences, but not with this kind of movement system and this level of polish. This is truly innovative. I've never been this immersed in an experience. I find having to use analog sticks to move in other games to be immersion breaking now. I love, love, love showing this off to friends. Even friends that have been somewhat lukewarm about VR in general, are absolutely blown away by this. Amazing job from this developer. I'm hoping for some dlc for this, but I'm even more excited about what this developer will come up with next. Once again, out-friggin-standing!

4.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 novembre 2021
A VR must play for everyone with a big enough space.

The whip and torch were great and I enjoyed the "progression" of your items getting better throughout the game (i won't spoil here). Definitely could use a left-hand mode; whipping was pretty difficult with my non-dominant hand!

Really enjoyed the puzzles and variety the game offers. Falling ceilings, the white tiles that move forward so you gotta dodge everything, the crushing pillars you have to time with the whip lever, etc.. the game doesn't get stale.

Final boss was challenging and great- like the old days where game mechanics you've already learned help you take him down. It was crazy how a little bit of pressure made me fall off a simple roller 2 or 3 times.

The story is not polished even in terms of indie games. The story torches were pretty barebones, voice acting passable but not great, and (without spoiling a lot) the bird at the end was too bright to see any detail. Turn her down! I want to see the textures!

Gameplay is still a solid 10 for innovation and fleshing out the concept.

I'll buy the sequel day one.

Évaluation publiée le 18 octobre 2021
It's certainly a very interesting game. You have to move only with your feet, no virtual movement controls in this game.
Graphic is not the strongest value of this game but pretty much acceptable considering its file size (it's only about 700MB). It feels repeating itself after some time but still have a lot of interesting parts from to time.

I think it's a very unique game but definitely not for PC VR. This game if for Oculus quest, stand alone device, not because of play space but the direction where player face. It requires only 1~2 square meters to play but the direction is 360 degrees. So If you play this game with PC VR, your line of the headset get tangled after some time. I had to pause the game several times to re-spin my body to untangle the line. I'm sure this game will be released for Oculus quest some time soon, so wait to buy it for stand alone device.

Since im playing this game in little dosis (due to beeing sensitive to motion sickness) im gonna play it little by little and cant wait to proceed tomorrow.

Also i barely write any reviews but that games worth my time doing so.

Its a straight 10 / 10 for me.

Évaluation publiée le 15 octobre 2021
Alright here are some facts and some opinions:
1. If you own and know how to properly use [url=
]OVRAS[/url] then you don't need a 2m x 2m play space. You can use space drag just fine, and play this game sitting in your desk chair. This is what OVRAS is designed to do.; give us 3 legged people an opportunity to play games you normies can play, without it. I use the index, and have my right hand/left hand space drags bound to right/left touch pads and It didn't interfere with the controls at all. If you're one of the cool kids who uses OVRAS in Rec Room, then this will come easily and naturally.
2. The whipping is satisfying. It is rubbery and snappy and most importantly im glad I get to do this in VR versus real life or I'd be covered in lashes by now. And there is a bit of "combat" which surprised me. Unfortunately for the dev, this whipping simply made me want to go whip some bad guys over in Rec Room...
3. ...so yeah...45 minutes in and Im ready to go back to my normal title, but this is a fun and unique game. Show ur friends and laugh when they fall over.
4. Dont whip ur cat.

8.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 octobre 2021
Produit reçu gratuitement

In the past 7 years or so that I've been regularly using virtual reality headsets, I've had the opportunity to experience a bunch of great content and Eye of the Temple stands near or at the top of the best experiences that I've had.

I was given the opportunity to playtest Eye of the Temple back in 2020 and even though my living space is pretty small, I shoved everything I possibly could out of the way and barely made the nine steps required fit. In the game, you move forward, backward and to the center, left and right but only really one step in each direction based on the marvelous mechanic of standing on rolling tumblers or sliding blocks that keep you contained within that nine step boundary but also genuinely immersed within the temple game world.

Having a game with fully physical locomotion should be commonplace by now in VR, but Eye of the Temple is one of the rare games that takes advantage of your full room and puts you fully into the game world.

Armed with only a whip and a torch, you have to navigate perilous paths through and around a massive temple. You work to solve puzzles and defeat scarab enemies and booby traps along the way. There are shrines throughout the game that allow you to learn more of the narrated story of the temple's past. The entire game is quite well constructed and made me feel like I was on my very own Indiana Jones style adventure.

In my opinion, Eye of the Temple is a must have for any VR enthusiast and if you need to push the couch out to get more space, it is well worth it!

Évaluation publiée le 14 octobre 2021
Produit reçu gratuitement

Eye of the Temple ABSOLUTELY takes vr immersion to a new level. The unique style of having infinite room to move around due to the shifting blocks makes the game feel incredible to play. Half of the time I forget I have a headset attached to my face with a wire to my computer with how much I was walking around.
The gameplay is unlike I have seen on any other vr game. It really makes me feel like I am indiana jones, exloring the unknown mysteries of an unknown place. The thrills and surprises of each section make me wanting more of this game.
The graphics are gorgeous, and even my dinky little laptop that I used to test on half of the time was able to run the game smoothly (though with a high-powered desktop the game certainly is better).
I'm so happy to have found this game because I do not think there is anything like it on the market, vr or not vr. It is a fun experience with plenty of opportunities to prove yourself to be the best explorer (speedrunning the game is incredibly fun).

The only "warning" I would give for the game is that you probably want to have your "VR legs" prior to trying this game. Walking around so much on the moving platforms can be quite tricky if you are not used to it already. That being said, throwing my friend into the game for his first time in vr was quite the show for me, and a fun time for him.

Some hot stuff here utilizes room scale VR to the fullest, and feels like you are invading a temple and breaking priceless artifacts to grab gems and screaming it belongs in a museum. The only down side is that they are not kidding about the room required.
